title: Great app for checking Clipper Card balance and use
comment: It's a very simple app but it works great.  Simply put your phone on your card (I used my Clipper Card) for a couple of seconds and the screen will show the remaining balance.  You can then slide over to view the last dozen or so trips you've made (mine showed both BART and Muni), or slide over again to view recent refills to the card.  Exactly what I wanted and only what I wanted.

title: Works as advertised!
comment: Great simple and functional app, worked fine for me with a Galaxy SIII checking on a San Francisco Golden Gate bridge special edition Clipper card. SIII users who haven't used NFC before should note that the reader is in the back center of the phone, so just hold your phone and then hold the face side of the card against the back center and it should pick up.

title: Great app, but wish I could disable NFC feature
comment: Ignore the idiots who complain that their transit card isn't supported. If you didn't read the description before you downloaded the app, you don't deserve to review the app.  My problem with this app is that the NFC feature is constantly on. Every time I placed my phone on my wallet, the app would open and create a new scanned card. I could not find a way to disable the NFC detection in the app without disabling it globally. It was enough of a pain that uninstalled an otherwise great app.

title: FareBot works on GNex with Clipper
comment: FareBot app works to read your SFMTA Clipper Card on your NFC equipped smartphone.  Beyond this neat little app, it would be nice to be able to use the Galaxy Nexus' Near Field Communications (NFC) chip directly as a fare card on MUNI, BART, etc. Additionally, as program author Eric Butler has stated, for those of us who are travelers and are accumulating collections of these cards from cities in the U.S. and abroad, it would be great if the smartphone's NFC capability could be used in multiple transportation systems.

title: Works great for PASMO cards
comment: If you travel to Tokyo frequently and use a PASMO card this app is great for quickly checking your balance. It's especially valuable if you need to know your balance before you arrive back in Japan, since there is no way to check your balance online without a special reader (that I don't own).  I would like to see this app support the Presto cards used in Toronto, though I'm not sure if this is possible due to technical limitations of the Presto card system.

title: Works perfectly on LG Nexus 4
comment: I only tested this on a Clipper Card (SF Bay Area). Works perfectly, although I wish there was a way to clear history on my scanned cards (I was playing around with the NFC and demonstrated its ability to communicate a bunch of times with my Clipper Card).   Gives detailed reports on balances and fares, and the coolest thing (I think) is it shows where you traveled via a Google map. Great app, no I don't have to visit the Clipper Card website unless I wanna add money (I usually do it at stations). Highly recommend.

title: Works for Clipper in Bay Area
comment: I have a galaxy Nexus running ICS 4.0 running version 2.0. Able to read the serial number and value of my card. Displays most agencies tags and has a tab for what was loaded onto the card. The read was prompt and accuracy was good. The Clipper website can have a 3-5 days lag on current value. FareBot will display the current balance. I'm hoping the next version will work with Androids OS TalkBack to read the tags. Would be a great help to sight impaired folks to know whats on their Clipper card.
